Layout: 1 column, 27 lines|Script: Written in angular Gothic script in brown ink|Decoration: On recto, 5-line blue initial [G] on green ground with brown penwork extending above and below in left marginal space. Penwork is decorated with a sun and cloud. On verso, 3-line red initial [U] on green ground with similar brown penwork flourishing.|Incorrectly previously identified as a book of hours leaf, still in a bound portfolio identifying it as a book of hour leaf. The inclusion of red ink instructions for the priest and titles such as "collecte" and "vers" show that this is instead a missal leaf.|Recto contains prayers to Saint Augustine and Gregory the Great|Bound into a black leather portfolio with the label "Dutch book of hours"

note: Layout: 1 column, 14 lines|Script: Written in a French Gothic textualis script in black ink|Decoration: Capitals touched in yellow, 1- to 2-line initials alternating in red and blue throughout, many of the 2-line initials decorated with areas of parchment left in reserve. Nine 3- to 4-line puzzle initials with penwork flourishes alternating in red and blue.|Binding: Bound in the 18th or 19th century using leather from an earlier binding in dark brown morocco over tan-colored leather over wooden boards, the morocco blind-tooled with a frame of triple fillets. The earlier morocco leather is very worn and covers the boards only partly, and the leather underneath is also worn. Traces of a single clasp on the front cover|Black stains from pilgrims' badges on fols. 18v-19r and 37v-38r|Provenance: Calendar contains dated obits of the Despaigne and the D'Assonleville families, who can be traced to Arras in Picardy in the 16th century. In the margin of leaf 49 verso, an 18th or 19th century inscription in black ink "Rollet est im fripon" (Rollet is a rascal).|Calendar is in French, Use of Rome in the Netherlands. The calendar lacks the feast of the Presentation of the Virgin (introduced in the Roman Missal in 1472, indicating possible production before 1472), added to the calendar in a later hand.|Names added to calendar: Martine Despaigne, d. 1555; Jacques Despaigne, d. 1559; Jeanne Despaigne, d. 1598; Julye Despaigne, d. 1580; Jacques Despaigne, d. 1559; Marie Despaigne, d. 1578; Marie D'Assonleville, d. 1586

Layout: 1 column, six staves of Gregorian notation with one line of text beneath each staff|Script: Written in a Gothic script in black ink|Decoration: Enlarged initials in red and blue with penwork flourishing in the alternate color|Fol. 1r has a banner colophon stating "Anno millesimo Quingentesimo Nonagesimo. Tempore R. de D. Abbatise Sororis Dorothee' Adurne' Monasteri, Sancti Leonardi Genne. P. Paulus Lambertus Scribebat."|Catchwords every four leaves.|Provenance: Written for a high-born resident of Genoa, Sister Dorothy Adorno, who belonged to a convent of nuns in Genoa.
